facts.text: Appeal by special leave granted by the Supreme Court on the 16th October, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave granted by the Supreme Court on the 16th October, 1952, from the decision dated the 22nd December, 1952, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India at Calcutta in Appeals Nos. Cal. 366/51, Cal. 69/52 and Cal. 70/52, arising out of the award dated the 9th February, 1952, of the Chairman, Industrial Tribunal, Delhi.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal of India at Calcutta gave decision dated September 22, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave from a decision dated September 22, 1952, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India at Calcutta setting aside an award dated February 9, 1952, made by the Industrial Tribunal constituted to adjudicate on certain disputes between the appellant, the Punjab National Bank Ltd., Delhi hereinafter referred to as the Bank  and its workmen, the respondents represented by their Union.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal made award dated February 9, 1952 refusing reinstatement of 150 employees.

anchor.surface_text: made by the Industrial Tribunal constituted to adjudicate on certain disputes between the appellant, the Punjab National Bank Ltd., Delhi hereinafter referred to as the Bank  and its workmen, the respondents represented by their Union. The facts leading to this appeal may be briefly stated.

facts.text: Several disputes between the Bank and its workmen referred on February 21, 1950 to Industrial Tribunal presided over by Sri K. S. Campbell-Puri.

anchor.surface_text: Several other disputes between the parties had already been referred on February 21, 1950, to another Industrial Tribunal presided over by Sri K. S. Campbell-Puri, and during the pendency of the proceedings before the said Tribunal,

facts.text: Bank alleged that respondents along with other workmen numbering more than a thousand commenced a general strike on April 18, 1951 during pendency of proceedings before Campbell-Puri Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: and during the pendency of the proceedings before the said Tribunal, the Bank alleged that the respondents along with other workmen numbering more than a thousand illegally commenced a general strike on April 18,1951, in connection with a fresh dispute.

facts.text: Notice issued to strikers that unless they returned to work by April 24, 1951, they would be deemed to have left service.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, notice was issued to the strikers that unless they returned to work by April 24, 1951, they would be deemed to have left service of their own accord. That notice having been ignored by the strikers a second notice was issued to them on April 27, 1951, terminating their service.

facts.text: Strikers ignored the first notice and second notice issued on April 27, 1951 terminating their service.

anchor.surface_text: That notice having been ignored by the strikers a second notice was issued to them on April 27, 1951, terminating their service. The Government of India thereupon intervened, and as a result of the discussions held between the Government officials and the Bank,

facts.text: Government of India intervened after strike and termination, Bank agreed to take back all employees except 150 against whom objections for subversive activities and other conduct.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of India thereupon intervened, and as a result of the discussions held between the Government officials and the Bank, the latter agreed to take back all the employees except 150 against whom the Bank had objections on account of their alleged subversive activities and other objectionable and unlawful conduct before and during the strike.

facts.text: Government of India constituted a Tribunal on July 2, 1951 to decide questions regarding dismissals of the 150 employees.

anchor.surface_text: On July 2, 1951, the Government of India constituted a Tribunal to decide the questions regarding the dismissals etc. of the aforesaid 150 employees, and that Tribunal, after calling for the statements of case on behalf of the parties and hearing them, made an award on February 9, 1951,

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal refused reinstatement of respondents on ground of illegal strike in contravention of section 23(b) of Industrial Disputes Act.

anchor.surface_text: refusing reinstatement on the sole ground that the respondents had gone on an illegal strike in contravention of section 23 b  of the Industrial Disputes Act, and that the Bank was entitled to dismiss them.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal granted compensation to respondents at half rates from date of dismissal to publication of award.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal, however, granted to the respondents compensation byway of salary and allowances at half the rates from the date of dismissal to the date of the publication of the award.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal agreed that the strike was illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents appealed to the Labour Appellate Tribunal at Calcutta which, while agreeing with the Industrial Tribunal that the strike was illegal, held that it was condoned by the Bank

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal held that the illegal strike was condoned by the Bank.

anchor.surface_text: held that it was condoned by the Bank and it was, therefore, not open to it to justify the dismissal of the respondents on the ground that they had participated in the illegal strike.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal held dismissal wrongful because no charges framed against respondents for violence or subversive activities and no explanation called for.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal further held that the dismissal of the respondents was wrongful because no charges were framed against any of them in respect of their alleged acts of violence or subversive activities and their explanation was not called for.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal directed further evidence on specific points and reserved decision on reinstatement.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal accordingly thought that further evidence was necessary on certain specific points mentioned in its, order and reserved its decision as to whether the respondents were entitled to reinstatement till after such evidence was taken.

facts.text: Proceedings pending before Sri K. S. Campbell-Puri Tribunal made the strike illegal under section 23(b).

anchor.surface_text: If the pendency of the proceedings before Sri Campbell-Puri made the strike of the respondents illegal under section 23 b  of the Act,

facts.text: No permission obtained from the Tribunal under section 33 for dismissal during pendency of proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: the dismissal of the respondents by the Bank without obtaining his permission as required by section 33 was also illegal.

anchor.surface_text: illegally commenced a general strike on April 18,1951, in connection with a fresh dispute. Thereupon, notice was issued to the strikers that unless they returned to work by April 24, 1951,

concepts.unlisted_description: Prohibits strikes or lock-outs during pendency of conciliation or tribunal proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: If the pendency of the proceedings before Sri Campbell-Puri made the strike of the respondents illegal under section 23 b  of the Act,

concepts.unlisted_description: Prohibits strikes or lock-outs during pendency of conciliation or tribunal proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: we are of opinion that section 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, furnishes a short answer to the further contention that the Appellate Tribunal had no jurisdiction to order reinstatement of the respondents. That section provides, inter alia, that no employer shall, during the pendency of any proceedings before a tribunal in respect of any industrial dispute, discharge by way of dismissal or otherwise, any workman concerned in the dispute save with the permission in writing of the said Tribunal.

concepts.interpretation: Terms are wide enough to cover the present case; place in Chapter VII (Miscellaneous) not inconsistent with general application to all discharges regardless of ground; confirmed by 1950 amendment omitting exception for misconduct unconnected with dispute.
concepts.unlisted_description: Requires employer permission from tribunal for dismissal of workman concerned in pending dispute.

anchor.surface_text: the dismissal of the respondents by the Bank without obtaining his permission as required by section 33 was also illegal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pendency of proceedings before tribunal that rendered strike illegal under s.23(b) also required prior permission under s.33 for any dismissal of concerned workmen; no permission obtained.
